trial_identification.studytitle: Preoperative oral paracetamol versus intraoperative intravenous paracetamol: plasma levels in the recovery room
trial_identification.scientifictitle: Does giving paracetamol intravenously during an operation result in significantly higher plasma paracetamol levels in the early postoperative period than giving the same dose orally as a premedicant?

primaryOutcome.outcome: Plasma paracetamol levels from venous blood sample taken from contralateral arm to the drip. Assay performed by Canterbury Health Laboratories using a colourimetric assay on the c8000 analysers. Units in mcmol/l.
primaryOutcome.timepoint: 30 minutes after arrival in the recovery room

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Postoperative pain scores at 10 minute intervals using a 100mm visual analogue scale (VAS)
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: 10 minute intervals until discharge from recovery
Total amount required during the patient's stay in recovery

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Duration of stay in recovery ie how long it took for patient to reach standard discharge criteria from recovery

eligibility.inclusivecriteria: Day case arthroscopies Suitable for laryngeal mask anaesthesia American Society of Anaesthesiologists (ASA) 1 & 2 Body mass index (BMI) less than 35
eligibility.exclusivecriteria: Contraindication to paracetamol BMI over 35 Requiring intubation rather than laryngeal mask airway (LMA) use Requiring any other intraoperative analgesics other than IV fentanyl

trial_design.concealment: Subjects enrolled by study investigator on the day of admission. Letter explaining trial also sent to patients prior to their surgery. Oral tablets (either active paracetamol or placebo) administered from sealed numbered envelopes. Placebo identical to active tablets. Tablets administered by blinded nurse.
trial_design.sequence: Randomised using a computer generated vector (prepared by our statistician).

ethicsAndSummary.summary: Paracetamol is traditionally given by anaesthetists in tablet form around one hour before an operation with the intention of providing good pain relief in the period following the operation. Recently, an IV formulation has become available and can be given during the operation. We compared which of these techniques gave higher levels of paracetamol in the bloodstream after the operation. We also looked at how much extra pain relief was needed in the recovery room, how long patients stayed in the recovery room and how sore they were.
